yoruba: À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú.
gold: Feeding-without-leaving kills the Tullberg's rat; feeding-without-departing kills the spotted grass mouse; feeding-without-departing kills the máláàjú rat.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú" can be translated to English as "It is the inability to stop eating that kills the monkey; it is the inability to stop eating that kills the fly; it is the inability to stop eating that kills the antelope."

This proverb highlights the dangers of excess and lack of moderation. It suggests that overindulgence or the inability to control one's desires can lead to one's downfall or demise. Each animal mentioned (the monkey, the fly, and the antelope) represents different aspects of life where excess can be harmful. The proverb serves as a warning to practice self-control and moderation in all aspects of life to avoid negative consequences.
